£519 Million Invested, £169 Million Left

The Lancashire County Pension Fund invested £519 million in a bond portfolio known as VeLTIP (Very Long-Term Investment Portfolio). Current valuations place its worth at approximately £169 million — a paper loss of approximately £350 million.

This is not a rounding error. This is a loss equivalent to more than a quarter of Lancashire County Council's entire net annual budget.

What Was VeLTIP?

VeLTIP was a bond portfolio designed to generate long-term returns for the Lancashire County Pension Fund. The strategy involved investing in long-duration fixed-income instruments — bonds that would pay a steady income over decades.

The problem: when interest rates rose sharply from 2022 onwards, the market value of these long-duration bonds collapsed. A bond paying 2% is worth far less when new bonds pay 5%. The mathematical relationship is straightforward and entirely predictable — yet the fund appears not to have adequately hedged against this scenario.

Who Knew, and When?

The critical question is one of transparency. The scale of the paper loss on VeLTIP was not prominently reported to councillors or the public during the final years of the Conservative administration. Reform UK, upon taking control in May 2025, brought the true position into the open.

The national Reform DOGE team has been providing remote support specifically on bond valuations and pension fund fee analysis — described by Atkinson as "a key piece of work that will save council taxpayers a lot of money."

Company Directors' Fees

Alongside the bond portfolio concerns, Reform identified and halted excessive company directors' fees being charged on pension fund investment vehicles. The pension fund's investment management arrangements involve multiple external fund managers, each with their own fee structures — and in some cases, associated company directorships carrying additional remuneration.

The Scale of the Problem

To put £350 million in context:

  • It is more than Lancashire's entire annual education budget
  • It is roughly equivalent to the combined annual budgets of all 12 Lancashire district councils
  • It exceeds the total cost of Lancashire's adult social care for an entire year
  • It represents approximately £250 for every person living in Lancashire

What Happens Now

The pension fund's actuarial position remains a matter of ongoing assessment. If interest rates decline, some of the paper loss may be recovered. However, the fundamental question of governance — why the scale of this exposure was not transparently communicated — remains unanswered.

This is exactly the kind of financial governance failure that the AI DOGE platform was built to expose.
